Cicero belongs to a type not unknown in English life, that of the statesman who is also a student and a · writer. From his youth he aspired to play a part in

public affairs, and the first step towards this ambition was to learn to speak. He approached Greek philo- sophy as part of a liberal education for a political career, and he looked on it as supplying themes for practice in oratory. But his real interest in it went deeper3 the study of it formed his mind and hu- manized his character, and he loved it to the end of his life. In his youth he heard the heads of the three chief ‘Schools of Athens, Phaedrus the Epicurean, Diodo- tus the Stoic, and Philo the Academic‚ who had come to Rome to escape the disturbances of the Mithradatic War.
